column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Classify Stars
#Text=Every star is different .
#Text=Some are big , some small , some hot , some cold .
#Text=They can be blue or yellow or red .
#Text=Stellar classification allows you to describe a star in simple terms .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Temperature
#Text=Determine the star 's colour .
#Text=Colour serves as a rough guide to temperature .
#Text=Currently , there are ten colours , each with an associated temperature range .
#Text=O class stars are blue/UV .
#Text=B class are blue-white , A class white , F yellow-white , G yellow , K orange and M red .
#Text=The other three classes are infrared .
#Text=L class appear very deep red in visual light .
#Text=Their spectra show alkali metals and metal hydrides .
#Text=T class are cooler than L class .
#Text=Their spectra show methane .
#Text=Y class are the coolest of all , and apply only to brown dwarves .
#Text=Their spectra are different to T and L class , but there is no definite definition .
#Text=Put a number after the letter to show precise temperature .
#Text=Within each colour , there are ten temperature bands , 0-9 , with 0 being hottest .
#Text=Thus , A0 is hotter than A5 , which is hotter than A9 , which is hotter than F0 ( as an example )
#Text=Size
#Text=Determine the star 's size .
#Text=A roman numeral , indicating the star 's size , is added after the temperature designation .
#Text=0 or Ia+ indicates a hypergiant star .
#Text=Ia , Iab and Ib represent supergiants ( bright , medium , dim ) .
#Text=II is bright giants , III giants , IV sub-giants , V main sequence stars ( the part of a stars life that it spends the most time going through ) and VI is sub-dwarfs .
#Text=A prefix of D indicates a white dwarf star .
#Text=Examples : DA7 ( white dwarf ) , F5Ia+ ( yellow hypergiant ) , G2V ( yellow main-sequence star ) .
#Text=The Sun is G2V .
#Text=Shortcut to Temperature and Size
#Text=Use a prism to split the star 's light .
#Text=This will give you a range of colours , called a spectrum , like what you get when you shine a torch through a prism .
#Text=The spectrum of a star should have dark lines on it .
#Text=These are absorption lines .
#Text=Compare the star 's spectrum to a database .
#Text=A good astronomical database should give a typical spectrum for each star type .
#Text=This is why the type is , sometimes called the spectral class .
#Text=Metallicity
#Text=Determine the proportion of metals ( elements other than hydrogen and helium ) in a star .
#Text=Stars with greater than 1 % metals are termed metal-rich , and are part of something called Population I. Stars with about 0.1 % metals are termed metal-poor , and are part of Population II .
#Text=Population II stars formed earlier in the universe , when less metals had been formed .
#Text=Keep your eyes open for stars with no metals .
#Text=These stars ( Population III ) are expected to have been born just after the Big Bang , when the only elements were hydrogen and helium , and metals did not exist .
#Text=As of yet , these stars are only theoretical , but people are looking very hard for them .
#Text=Variability
#Text=Determine if the star is variable .
#Text=Not all stars are , but some are , and can be very useful .
#Text=Determine if it is an eclipsing binary .
#Text=Eclipsing binaries , like Algol in Perseus , are two stars orbiting each other .
#Text=Determine the amplitude and period of the variation .
#Text=Compare these to the characteristics of known variable types to determine the type of variable star .

#Text=For example , Cepheid variables have periods of days to months and amplitudes of up to 2 magnitudes , whereas Delta Scuti variables have periods of less than 8 hours , and amplitudes of less than 0.9 magnitudes .
